comments.commentBody: Northern Iowa was robbed.
I hope you're wrong in your pick, Mr. Myerberg. Fire Up, Chips!

Sorry, I couldn't resist bringing up Northern Iowa.  There was a team who beat Northern Iowa by 10 points.  South Dakota State beat them 24 to 14.  South Dakota State  lost to Minnesota 16 to 13.  How can anyone talk about the powerhouse "Big Ten" when they squeak by such teams on a regular basis.  Remember Michigan losing to Appalachian State, Michigan finished second in the Big Ten that year, not unlike Iowa this year.  Georgia Tech is one dimensional.  As Randy Shannon said of their option offense(as I remember), "if it was so great, everyone would use it."

#10Lee. Here is a bit of info for you. Nobody will play them. Boise has an open
date next year. It has said it will go anywhere to play anyone in the six BCS
conferences, on their home field. Guess what? No Takers.

Part of what explains the trend is the SEC clearly separating itself from the other conferences in talent over the course of the decade, largely due to a decline in the major ACC programs.

Here is a chart showing the 3-year moving averages of Rivals 100 recruits by conference over the past several years (full 2010 recruiting class numbers based on current commitment numbers).

It appears that the top talent that was going to Miami, Florida State, and other ACC programs earlier in the decade is now going to SEC programs.

True, maybe there should be longer odds on the Bengals, but 50-1 on the Jets seems fitting. I think they are looking at the rookie QB, and at games like the 10-7 loss to Atlanta, and asking: if this team does not manage to totally shut down the other guys in the playoffs, can they outscore them? Like, if they were to hold the Chargers or Colts to 20 points, will they get 21?

The Cardinals were long shots last year but they had a scoring machine ... and the Steelers prevailed over them in the SB by just managing to outscore them, in a scenario similar to that posed above. (A good D held the Cards to "only" 21, and got a crucial defensive score, then an experienced QB led a late drive to secure the win.) In fact, looking at this year's odds, nearly all of the teams from Chargers down thru the Cards are capable of racking up big numbers on a pretty regular basis. This appears to be the year of the high-powered offense. Twill be interesting to see if the Jets can buck that trend.
It's the most remarkable shop in all the world!

Ms. habib,

I must say that after having read your article I could not really empathize with your plight. Firstly because you no longer are a Pakistani, you are a Canadian. As far as being an Ahmadi is concerned, I am fully aware of the persecution that they are going through in Pakistan but that has got nothing to do with the new TSA rules. If radical Muslims are bringing shame upon the rest of the Muslim nation and choose to take the route of violence to achieve their goals, whatever they are, then how should we expect the rest of the world to react? I am not a big fan of US policy but we have to be realistic here. Stringent checking is very important if the government has to ensure the safety of its citizens. You must be aware of the recent plot at the detroit airport on Christmas. Please, where there is nothing harming our belief, we should extend our full cooperation.

This facility was long overdue.

Transfer cases???

Watch the Canadians, the British, the Scots, the Germans, the French, the Swedes, the Dutch, the Ukrainians, and others, and learn how they treat and speak about their retuning war dead.

Transfer case, indeed.

Dead soldiers, sailors, air-force persons and Marines being labeled like carcasses is about par for the course in this sad United States where the poor and the marginalized do the dying whereas the son and daughters of the rich elites make billions on Wall Street from the wars.

This veteran finds this whole sordid business a shame.

". . . The United States cannot send troops throughout the world . . . " just what are you talking about with that bit of nonsense?

The United States has over 700 bases throughout the world, and troops in almost every continent. Soon, the
African Command will have the entire 173rd AB Brigade as their "point of the spear" to heave into Africa.

There are troops in places about which the United States does not want you to know, and the surged 30.000 more troops are now heading into Afghanistan and Pakistan, and probably Kashmir before long.

That is just the beginning, just as the first 19,000, and now the surged 30,000 were/are not enough, because the real total that the generals want is 600,000--and they will get them.

This article is a propaganda puff-piece of disinformation. Start printing the truth.

Lieberman and McCain need to be removed to Iraq now, and they can report on the future perfect when that arrives.

I suspect that before that future perfect arrives, that both of them would return to Dover AFB in "transfer cases."
That would be present perfect.

"the official opening at Dover of the Center for the Families of the Fallen, an expansive space of soothing lighting, soft carpeting and overstuffed sofas."

Is this a terrible joke? The solution is to expand the facility so we can bring back more dead soldiers? What about getting us out of these meaningless wars so we won't need an ever bigger facility!

Their is a motive to every carefully orchestrated plan. The attempted christmas day attack would not have ocurred in the first place if pentagon did not sponser a deadly air raid in Yemen no less than a week before the incident. Yemen special forces used US fighter planes and logistical information to attack a potential Al Qaeda member. In that raid 82 civilians were killed and more than 213 were injured. Most of them were women and children from the nomad community in the district. This was the first attack of its kind in yemen, a very unneccessary one. The US persuaded the Yemeny government in going thru with the attack by feeding them unaccounted information that Al Qaeda was targeting the presidents family members.
Freedom House recently noted Yemen as among the world’s most corrupt developing nations. With the personal interests of the ruling elite taking priority over national development. Nearly half of Yemeni children are malnourished and out of school. Unemployment is extremely high and medical services scarce. A looming water crisis continues to threatens to destabilize the country. Claims of development are little more than government propaganda (managed by US consulting firms). Year after year the gap between the extremely rich and the extremely poor widens.
Yemen has been a failed government ever since the US started sponsering the government under Ali Abdullah Saleh... it led to the unification of North & South Yemen. In 2009 it has been ranked 154/180 on Transparency International's Corruption Perceptions Index. There is a movement in South Yemen as well as a separate one in North Yemen that seeks to overthrow the corrupt regime under President Ali Abdullah Saleh. A "democratically elected" president who made sure his family members and son will forever run the nation. The presence of Al Qaeda is extremely small and poses no eminent threat to US or Yemeni interest. By sponsering the corrupt Yemeni government we are suppressing these legitimate reform/resistance movements... the same type of movements we failed to back up in Iraq after the first gulf war, the same type of movements that we're pushing for in Iran now (while endorsing sanctions and non-stop war mongering). This type of foreign policy is turning into a deadly norm, not to the US citizens but to those people who truly strugle to live in a free society of their own. God save the citizens of yemen, not from the US military but from their own dirty government who are fooled by ours.
if I could draw the critter I would put that in instead of the three letters!  I remember thinking this was quite an author , (especially if English is not first language?)

IKEBANA made a hard puzzle a little easier. Thanks, Martin. A Van Morrison fan, I should have had 32A a bit quicker.

Well it's a marvelous night for a moondance
With the stars up above in your eyes
A FANTABULOUS night to make romance
'Neath the cover of October skies

I was actually surprised to see it in the dictionary. I thought the word was just made up for the song.

Anyway, great puzzle! Loved it. Nice work, Xan.

To quote Philly Solver, oy vey! One of the hardest (that's good) and cleverest (very good!) ever. My favorite clue was [Yours may be asleep while you're awake]. I only had the G. First I thought maybe "doG" though that seemed like a long shot (though accurate). So I went through the alphabet for both missing letters - more or less simultaneously - hoping that the middle one would be a vowel. LEG was a pure lol. I mentioned on Wednesday that I prefer solves that take a long time. This took a long time.

I am glad the Ikebana came up as I wondered about the proper pronunciation.
http://www.merriam-webster.com...
I am happy that SHANE finally came back, but sad to see my paper turned into a formicary.

never thought i'd finish this one -- that sw corner being the toughest for me. while there's something about all those ANTs and PEST CONTROL that gives me the JIM-JAMS (*what* a great word!), thought this puzzle was F{ANT}ABULOUS.

bravi, xan 'n' will!!

;-)

I'm on vacation.  Sometimes I play the puzzle in the lobby of whatever hotel I'm in because my laptop has a habit of resetting in the middle of the game.  I didn't have trouble yesterday, but today I only stayed in the lobby long enough to see that it had something to do with bugs.  I couldn't concentrate, so I came upstairs and finished on acrosslite.  I liked it once I settled down, but I'm more familiar with the Pirate Parrot than Mr. Met.

Jim, I was so glad to read your blog, because I felt stoopid that I couldnt quite finish this one...was going to go for the "give up in disgust" technique, but as usual settled for the "look it up" technique.
Am one of the ones who loves rebus puzzles so reallky enjoyed it; thanks Xan and Will!

n.b. Martin, that Ikebana picture is exquisite...!

Thanks, Xan, for a brilliant puzzle. A rebus puzzle with a hint of Jeremiah Farrell's CLINTON/BOB DOLE puzzle, where you have one clue and two possible answers. It required just the right amount of sweat to solve, with a delicious payoff. Loved everything about it. Wow.
16 across is a stretch. Great puzzle though.

Crowne Plaza Beijing is located in Wangfujing Street. The Dongdan Business Street, the Forbidden City, the Tian'anmen Square, the Beihai Park and the National Art Gallery are all within easy reach from the hotel.

more Beijing Hotels

Just returned from Guadeloupe where we stayed at La Plantation Resort Golf & Spa. I & my husband had an apartment overlooking the swimming pool, spacious and very comfortable.
Everything was a pleasure! the staff was very helpful and I would especially recommend the SPA, it was Heaven! the staff is "top French quality service" so professiona! We came back so relaxed and can't wait to go back, one of the best massages and treatment I ever had!
http://www.laplantationresort.fr/

If that moron Trent Dilfer (I can't get over how shockingly insipid his "analysis" on ESPN is) could win a Super Bowl with such dreadful turnover numbers, I think the Jets have a legitimate chance at making a playoff run.
